sub_title: Retired, former manager ECPAT at Defence for Children – ECPAT Netherlands
summary:
Experience in general
Expert in multi-stakeholder cooperation in corporate social responsibility and sustainability. Extended experience in program,  project and event management;  in working with the media, with politicians, with policy makers, with government and non government agencies, with the private sector at the national and international level ( UN, Council of Europe, EU, OSCE)
Main fields: 
- children’s and human rights; development cooperation; CSR in tourism; CSR  in ICT
- advocacy, lobby, campaigning, marketing & communication, consumer and business to business 
- research, training development

projects.title: Down to Zero
projects.description:
Down to Zero 

The Down to Zero program is a joint effort of Terre des Hommes Netherlands, Plan Netherlands, Defence for Children - ECPAT, Free a Girl and ICCO Cooperation and local partners and stakeholders with the aim to eradicate commercial sexual exploitation of children in 11 countries in Asia and Latin America. Defence for Children -ECPAT and partners in the ECPAT network will be active in India, Indonesia, Philippines, Thailand and Brazil, Dominican Republic.  The Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs is a strategic partner of the Alliance and the donor of this programme. This runs from 2016-2020 and includes activities;
 
●	enabling children and youth to protect themselves and stand up for their rights: 
-	raising awareness on child rights and the risks of commercial sexual exploitation
-	ensuring that children get access to child protection systems
-	providing appropriate services and support to child victims
-	enabling children to act as agents of change. 
●	supporting and enabling communities to protect their children 
-	raising awareness campaigns, hold dialogues with community leaders and role models
-	establishing community based child protection mechanisms
-	initiating discussions with families and providing care and counseling to help their children escape from exploitative situations. 
●	encouraging governments to execute relevant policies and laws, 
-	assisting in the development and implementation of National Action Plans that can effectively address commercial sexual exploitation.
-	Engaging with governments and law enforcement agencies to put commercial sexual exploitation higher on their agendas 
●	cooperating with the private sector (for example with tourism companies)
-	Codes of conduct are being developed with and for companies on protection of children
-	engaging with companies and their customers, to call for detection and prevention of commercial sexual exploitation of children in their supply chain.

projects.title: Mario Project to protect children on the move in Europe
projects.description:
Mario is since 2009 a partnership of major child protection NGOs in Europe led by Terre des Hommes and with ECPAT, Save the Children in Albania and Nobody’s Children Foundation to provide more effective intervention and advocacy for Central and South Eastern European (C/SEE) migrant children at risk of abuse, exploitation and trafficking.
Mario aims at improving the protection of C/SEE migrant children through transnational outreach research, advocacy, trainings and direct support to professionals and empowerment of C/SEE at-risk migrant children –  multilateral solutions are being sought for the problems that children face prior, during or after migration and that require coordinated protection. Services are to be provided with a strong emphasis put on child participation. 
The Mario project in 2013 extended its activities to 16 countries and 19 partners. In 2016 the overall objective of the project is to enable stakeholders to address the vulnerability of children on the move at local and regional levels and strengthen cooperation of authorities across borders.
At transnational level Mario partners design and jointly implement a common advocacy action plan that will address authorities’ failure to find multilateral solutions to the situation of C/SEE migrant children that concern virtually all countries in Europe. Therefor Mario partners will implement joint regional advocacy actions underlining the common challenges that all European countries face when handling C/SEE migrant children cases and develop a multilateral protection framework that will be closely designed with European countries’ relevant Ministries and the EC..
The countries involved at the national level are Albania, Kosovo, Bulgaria, Romania and Poland. Transnational activities are in Italy, Netherlands, Belgium, Greece, Macedonia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, Montenegro, Hungary, Czech Republic, Slovakia.
Mario is co-funded by the European Union’s Daphne III and the Oak Foundation.

projects.title: Reducing Sexual violence against children, with special focus on sexual exploitation of children and child sex tourism
projects.description:
Defence for Children – ECPAT Netherlands with 24 partners financed by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs implemented the ‘Reducing Violence against Children’ project in 30 countries in Africa, Asia, Europe and Latin America, focusing on sexual exploitation of children and child sex tourism.
The objective was to ensure a greater, more effective Civil Society response. This was achieved by increasing awareness, strengthening Civil Society Organisation (CSO) capacity, networks and multi-stakeholder cooperation through referral systems.The Global Study on Sexual Exploitation of Children in Travel and Tourism, resulted in 14 national assessments which feed into the report that will be published in 2016.
Awareness raising activities by 21 partners through the dissemination of over 297,000 information materials, the organising of 265 seminars for the travel and tourism industry on sexual exploitation, the conducting of 81 trainings for relevant practitioners, policy makers and other stakeholders in child protection, social welfare, justice, health, education and the establishment of 163 youth groups acting as mobilisers in the community. Focusing on research-based lobby and advocacy, 18 partners have conducted research and 13 partners have collectively held 273 meetings with local, national, regional and international authorities. Ten partners enhanced cooperation through 61 multi-sectoral/multi-stakeholder activities with 1,390 participants. Referral mechanisms were strengthened through the establishment of 84 referral protocols, 93 information activities on where and how to report cases and 250 network meetings. Capacity of CSOs was strengthened by 127 initiatives, 76 organisational policies and 49 trainings to enhance knowledge and skills of staff. Over 3,280 children received socio-legal services, 1,579 children received medical and psychological support services and shelter, and 2,864 children received life skills, assets building and vocational training.

projects.title: Girl Power
projects.description:
The Equal Rights and Opportunities for Girls and Young Women in short GIRL POWER programme of the Dutch Child Rights Alliance led by Plan Nederland further consists of Child Helpline International, Free Press Unlimited, International Child Development Initiatives  and Women Win and Defence for Children-ECPAT (DCI-ECPAT). The  total programme runs in Bangladesh, Bolivia, Ethiopia, Ghana, Liberia, Nepal, Nicaragua, Pakistan, Sierra Leone and Zambia and is supported by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs.The goal is the elimination of violence against girls and young women, such as domestic and intimate partner violence, sexual violence and psychological violence as well as sexual exploitation, trafficking and harmful practices, like female genital mutilation, forced marriage and child marriage. Girl Power aimed to strengthen civil society in promoting and ensuring the right of girls and young women to protection from all forms of violence.

DCI-ECPAT partners are FSCE, ECPAT in Ethiopia; GNCRC- ECPAT affiliate in Ghana, DCI - Ghana;  DCI-Ghana, DCI - Sierra Leone and  CHIN-ECPAT affiliate in Zambia
.
Through Girl Power:
• Girls and young women have been reached by awareness, knowledge and skills building measures like Girls Clubs that teach girls about their rights and offer them skills training.
• girls and young women have been reached by socio-legal assistance when at risk or whenvictims of violence.
• Parents, families, women and men, community leaders, girls and boys have been reached by sensitization measures.
• Child protection structures at national, district and local levels have been established and strengthened.
• advocacy and lobby have led to better protection of girls and young women against violence, through improved Law & Policy and social (child) protection services delivery.
• Governmental and other professionals like school teachers have been trained.
• Local civil society organizations and community based organizations have improved capacity.

projects.title: Don't Look Away
projects.description:
“Don’t Look Away!” is a 3-year project involving members of the ECPAT network from 16 European countries.and six countries outside Europe: Belgium, Brazil, Bulgaria, Germany, Estonia, France (coordinator), Gambia, Italy, Kenya, Luxembourg, Madagascar, the Netherlands, Austria, Ukraine, Poland, Romania, Senegal, Spain, United Kingdom, South Africa and Switzerland. The information material is available in thirteen European languages.The project is co-funded by the European Union and supported by other public and private actors,including from the tourism sector.
The project aims to strengthen the protection of children and young people from sexual exploitation at the hands of tourists or travellers through the following four components:

(1) Information campaigns to raise public awareness (of tourists and travellers in particular).
(2) Research on the sexual exploitation of children in travel and tourism.
(3) The creation and promotion of online reporting mechanisms to facilitate the reporting of suspected cases of sexual exploitation of children in the context of travel and tourism.
(4) Mobilising the support and strengthening the capacity of key stakeholders such as the tourism sector, the police and local/state authorities.

www.reportchildsextourism.eu contains the reporting sites of European countries. When someone from a European country has a suspicion of child sex tourism, he/she can go to the website and click on the country flag to find where this can be reported. 

Dont Look Away in the Netherlands was launched on March 26, 2015 by Minister Van der Steur of Security and Justice at Schiphol Airport enabling international action across borders It is a collaboration of the border police, the national police, meldkindersekstoerisme.nl, ANVR, TUI, ECPAT, Terre des Hommes, Plan and Free a Girl.

Research into sexual exploitation of children in travel and tourism was done in five African countries: The Gambia, Kenya, Madagascar, Senegal and South Africa.

projects.title: Make It Safe!
projects.description:
In the two year  "make-IT-safe peer expert training project" with support from the EU children and youngsters have been taught how to use the internet and smart phones safely and how to use social media in a responsible way.

The project is based on the peer to peer principle, which allows youngsters (peer experts) to learn how to use new technologies and the media, as well as prevention of online violence, in a safe way and to pass the information and the knowledge to people of the same age. The project was supported by special trained teachers and youth leaders, the so-called "Coaches"

The "make-IT-safe peer expert training project" was conducted by ECPAT groups with relevant stakeholders in five countries: Germany ( ECPAT Germany was the overall coordinator), Austria, Belgium, the Netherlands and UK. Thanks to this materal in seven different languages was produced: Arabic, English, French, German, Netherlands, Turkish, Servo Croat.

The information provided on this Website concerning Online Risks, Information for Parents and Youth Leaders and helpful Addresses have been conducted in conjunction by the five ECPAT groups and the national peer experts and coaches during the two year runtime of the project.

Material produced

Brochure for parents: online behaviour of children
It is important for parents to integrate online behaviour and experiences of their child into their parental care. This brochure provides useful advice to lead this conversation with your children and youngsters.

 
Manual for peer experts (peer2peer) and Manual for coaches
These manuals provides concrete recommendations about implementing issues like online security through the peer-2-peer concept.

 Comics on data privacy and safety
Comics: "Password..., Meeting with a stranger..., One clic too many..." about risks and online safety

Awareness materials in Dutch,English,Arabic,Turkish,Servo-Croat,Romanian,Russian,French, German,Polish, Vietnamese, Bengali, Hindi, Punjabi, Urdu

company.name: Defence for Children - ECPAT The Netherlands

profile_positions.description:
Main activities and responsibilities:  International and national program management; Member management team;  lobby and advocacy; marketing communication PR- spokes person for the media; action research; cooperation with tourism industry and ICT sector; training development: international representative.

Manager of international programs on trafficking in children, sexual exploitation of children including in travel and tourism and in pornography. Expertise in multi-country programs with partners in many countries in Western, Central and Eastern Europe, South East Asia, Africa and Latin America: Down to Zero program; Girl Power Program; Don’t Look Away Program and the project Reducing Sexual Violence against children, with special focus on sexual exploitation of children and child sex tourism. Engaged in the Global Study on the sexual exploitation of children in travel and tourism published in 2016.

Engaged since 2008 in strengthening the capacity of civil society organisations in countries in Africa, Latin America, Asia and Europe to lobby and advocate and cooperate with relevant stakeholders in government and private sector. 

Coordinator of the 2002-2004 Joint East West Research and the 2004-2006 Joint East West Multi Stakeholder Training Program on Trafficking in Children for Sexual Purposes in 19 countries. Since 2009 partner in the Mario program, an anti- child trafficking program in SE-Europe.

From 2007-2015 member of the International NGO Council on Violence against children, for ECPAT International. 

Involved in the 2009-2012 ECPAT –The Body Shop campaign STOP Sex Trafficking in Children and Young People, and the organisation of the STOP petitions at national and international level. 

Since 1998 involved in the Tourism Child Protection Code, work closely with NGO partners in countries of origin and destination and the private sector, since 2013 in the executive board.

Since 2009 member of eNACSO, the European NGO Alliance on Child safety online
profile_positions.title: Manager ECPAT

profile_positions.description:
From 1998 -2016 a governing position in Meldpunt Kinderporno, Dutch hotline on Child Pornography on the Internet which is a member of INHOPE (International Association of Internet Hotlines). Meldpunt Kinderporno is since 1999 involved in a surfsafe campaign giving tips to children and since 2008 providing a helpline to children and young people victims of sexual abuse and exploitation online. Involved in the Dutch multistakeholder platform on child safety online since 2008. 
Coordinator of Meldpunt from 2008-2012
profile_positions.title: Manager/executive board member

profile_positions.description:
Member of the executive board of ECPAT International, and chair of its credentials committee from 2005-2011 and advisory on trafficking issues, child pornography issues and child sex tourism issues. 

Contributed to several ECPAT International publications like Violence against Children in Cyberspace and the Ten Years Anniversary of the Stockholm Agenda for Action. 
Co-editor for publications Research on Trafficking in Children (2004); A Training guide on Combating Trafficking in Children (2006), Q&A on Trafficking in Children (2006). The Train the Trainer Training guide (2008). 

Partcipated in the Yokohama Second World Congress (2001) and in the Ljubljana Yokohama review for Europe and Central Asia (2005). Involved in the preparatory process for the 2008 World Congress III against the sexual exploitation of Children and adolescents for Europe and CIS and advised on the Congress Theme paper on Trafficking in Children. 

Member of the ECPAT International advocacy team for the Council of Europe Convention against sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children (2006-2007) and for the EU directives on Trafficking in Human beings (2009-2011) and on Sexual abuse, sexual exploitation of children and child pornography (2010-2011).
profile_positions.title: Executive Board member

profile_positions.description: Main activities and responsibilities PR (free publicity in relevant media), advertising, events organisation; Text writer, advisor text writers and designers.
profile_positions.title: Strategic Communication Advisor

profile_positions.description:
Main activities and responsibilities:  International and national program management; Member management team;  lobby and advocacy; marketing communication PR- spokes person for the media; action research; cooperation with tourism industry and ICT sector; training development: international representative.

Manager ECPAT campaign in the Netherlands. Since 1998 involved in the Code of Conduct for the protection of children from sexual exploitation in tourism and work closely with NGO partners in countries of origin and countries of destination and the private sector.  Since 1997 in the UN World Tourism Organisation network to protect children from (sexual) exploitation in Tourism.

In 2003 ECPAT merged with Defence for Children International Netherlands.
